There has been some smack-talking re:my 8,000 different rewards cards and stupid finance tricks
so I dumped the numbers in a spreadsheet
and in grad school, Stupid Finance Tricks have returned >$5,044.43 to me
and >$2500 to friends and associates
(not including things like the Google Voice landline bridge, Republic Wireless, short-term parking space rentals, &etc)
If I lie to myself about my hours, I currently make $14.40/hour
(realistically ~$10/hour, which is below Alameda County's minimum wage)
stupid tricks → 10 working weeks' post-tax cashdollars
it's all set-and-forget, and the rate per year has been increasing such that $2000 of that was in the last 12 months
so... it's something
if automated Stupid Tricks make me $20k over the next decade, it'll compare favorably to most peoples' art sideprojects :wink:
and $2k/year reduction in expenses represents a ~$50k reduction in what I need to save to be financially independent
$5.50 a day is probably McBreakfast and a McCoffee at McDonald's :simple_smile:
anyway, numbers are good and you should use them wherever possible

ah, I thought you were asking if the funds would be in bitcoin
i misunderstood
My question is: How are they providing infrastructure in such a way that there is autonomy from their organization?
Is multisig something that's built into the bitcoin protocol?
(Reading TFM)
let me know what you find
yeah, let me know if you have any questions
With a *Coinbase Managed* vault, Coinbase manages all of the security
it's nice because multiple people can still be notified and/or have to sign off on withdraw requests
it's not nice because Coinbase maintains your private keys
and if Coinbase gets screwed up, you might be screwed
with a *User Managed* vault, the users hold the keys
it's nice because you're totally fine if Coinbase gets screwed up
it's not nice because you're screwed if too many of your users lose their keys
For this test *ASCA Vault*, there are five users and three need to provide their keys to okay a transaction
here's the official *User Managed* tl;dr: <https://www.coinbase.com/multisig>
Okay, so here's what I've found out.
It's a slick system, but there's still some infrastructure that needs to be built.
<https://github.com/coinbase/multisig-tool>

attachments.title: coinbase/multisig-tool
attachments.text: multisig-tool - Multisig Vault recovery tool
attachments.fallback: GitHub: coinbase/multisig-tool

text: So <@U0A6T0LNT> correct me if I'm wrong, but my understanding is that there are two parameters to tweak: Standard or Group vault, and Coinbase Managed or Multisig vault.
Yeah, I know.
Check at the bottom of that README.
yes, correct
So all options aside from Group - Multisig are totally covered at the moment.
Super cool.

The open source solution doesn't support private key recovery for multisig group accounts yet, so if you want to get the advantages of security and access despite Coinbase involvement, you'd better know how to combine your keys yourself.

So for the information of the channel, the way the Standard Multisig vault works is that a 2 out of 3 private key encryption scheme is generated, you get two out of three private keys, and Coinbase gets two out of three as well.
The key you and Coinbase share is password protected, so Coinbase cannot make use of this shared key unless you provide them with the credentials to do so.
But because they have one additional private key, you can access funds through coinbase with only one of your private keys, and in particular, using only a password if desired.
But because you have access to two private keys, these can be combined (along with the password) to generate the completed private key needed to access the associated bitcoin address.
So it provides a certain level of "account recovery" capability without giving Coinbase any unilateral capability.
The utility that <@U0A6T0LNT> linked to is a front-end to the algorithm to combine the two private keys you have access to in order to get into the vault without Coinbase's involvement.
Unfortunately: "There is also currently no support for group vaults."
So the group vaults system works a bit differently - in this case, Coinbase gets no private keys, and 3 or 5 private keys are distributed to different individuals.
I'm not certain what algorithm they're using for combination of the keys, or how this system interacts with the Coinbase interface.

My understanding for the "Coinbase Managed Group" accounts is that the originating user is in charge of the account as usual, but requires *email* verification from a majority of cosigners to initiate a transaction.
So I don't know how this is adapted for group multisig - obviously email wouldn't be a sufficient method of verification in this context.
References: <https://support.coinbase.com/customer/portal/articles/1743782>

text: <@U0A6V6PHS>: so am I right to say that we want *User Managed Multisig*, and that the big question is whether we can figure out how to combine our keys on our own in case Coinbase eats it?
I worked through the key generation and account config and it takes you to a backup PDF you can print
the backup PDF has a bunch of technical information that I can't find elsewhere on the Coinbase site
This thing is a *Hierarchical Deterministic Multisig (HDM) wallet*
"The vault is comprised of many *P2SH multisig addresses*"
they are *BIP16* addresses, and the wallet is a *BIP32* wallet
Seed Format: Bitcoin private key in *WIF*
:simple_smile: !!!
Seed Encryption: *BIP38*
Seed to BIP32 wallet: *BitcoinJS*
order of pubkys in *P2SH*: *lexicographical*
BIP32 paths: *m/n* (m/0, m/1, ...)
whatever that means!
but that sounds like the information we need to combine our keys manually and get into the wallet
Yeah, that should be sufficient technical specifications to take care of business.
so from a UX perspective, we should figure out what it's like to take money out a) when Coinbase is a-okay and b) if Coinbase is compromised
<http://www.soroushjp.com/2014/12/20/bitcoin-multisig-the-hard-way-understanding-raw-multisignature-bitcoin-transactions/>

attachments.title: How to insulate a camper van
attachments.text: We just bought a new Mercedes Sprinter Van (2013, 144&quot; with high roof) and are starting the conversion towards a winterized camper. We live in the Pacific Northwest and love to ski - our goal is to drive the sprinter around ski resorts and camp out in the parking lots, ready for the next day powder! The construction of this van is for us the start of uncountable adventures discovering the area around here. We are outdoors enthusiasts, love to do backpack camping and backcountry skiing, but we also want to have a bit more comfort, specifically in the winter. The first step was, of course, to insulate the walls, the floor and the ceiling of the van to keep the warmth in. After reading multiple blogs and info sites about Sprinter and van conversions, we decided to use metallic bubble wrap, fiberglass insulation, and a plastic vapor barrier. In ...
attachments.fallback: Instructables.com: How to insulate a camper van

<!channel>: anyone else get wrecked in any of the financial data breaches this year?
<@U0B0A0NAX>: Did you buy something on... The Internet?
I haven't seen anything suspicious on any of my cards yet, but I have no reason to believe that that info isn't out there somewhere.
Patreon actually had a security breach, which wasn't great.
No financial info got released, I believe, but some other identifying information (SSN's for people wanting tax-deductibility of donations, etc.) got out.
my information was stolen on the Europe trip in 2006, but that's the only thing I've ever had
(card wasn't stolen, but it was used to buy hundreds of dollars worth of stuff in Rome)
Were you able to reverse the charges?
yeah, but it required going to a notary, etc, etc
it took way more effort than it should have to get the credit card company to understand that I still had the physical card

I've never had a large-scale fraud like that, but something I've experienced recently was a small fraudulent monthly charge (I think it was either $9.99 or $19.99 per month) that I did not recognize/never signed up for.  It looked like some kind of people-finder service (I forget the name but it was similar to <http://whitepages.com|whitepages.com>), but when you looked closely at the transaction ID it was missing a letter of their business name.  So, clearly designed to be overlooked.  I was able to get refunded for 2-3 months' worth of charges and have all further transactions from that company blocked.  Then US bank sent me a new card (the REI card-- 1% cash back, 2% on groceries and gas).  Very painless.
But be on the lookout for small monthly charges-- I'm guessing that is what the smart fraudsters use.

text: <@U0A6T0LNT|brandon> uploaded a file: <https://gwusbdhdu.slack.com/files/brandon/F0DAYGCEP/asca-2015-10-27.png|asca-2015-10-27.png> and commented: <@U0A6V6PHS>, <@U0A6Z2QE4>, <@U0A6XP8JF>, and <@U0B0A0NAX>: we're ready for takeoff!
Seems like things have been pretty quiet in our puddle
but it has provided me a lot of value in the past!
I really like the ASCA concept!
now let's see if we can build an ASCA _outside_ of any particular financial corporation
(I mean, we could just have a bucket somewhere)
we should put some money in
and try to take it out without coinbase
well, first we should try to take it out _with_ coinbase
to see if it's a good balance of straightforward and annoying

<@U0A6T0LNT|brandon> uploaded a file: <https://gwusbdhdu.slack.com/files/brandon/F0DB3109E/re_armory.txt|re:Armory> and commented: This looks promising!

file.name: re_Armory.txt
file.title: re:Armory
file.preview:
What If Armory Goes Out Of Business... How Will I Access My Coins?

All Armory source code can be found on GitHub. It is also found on other parts of the internet intended for archiving and saving this kind of information, such as GoogleCode and Amazon Web Services. In order for Armory to “disappear,” basically the internet would have to be wiped out, along with most of the people who ever used or installed Armory (including all the people who ever understood the code). Not only that, but the algorithm for converting your paper backup to your signing keys is publicly available, and could easily be implemented in other applications without needing Armory. In other words, it's effectively impossible for this to happen.
file.preview_highlight:
What If Armory Goes Out Of Business... How Will I Access My Coins?


All Armory source code can be found on GitHub. It is also found on other parts of the internet intended for archiving and saving this kind of information, such as GoogleCode and Amazon Web Services. In order for Armory to “disappear,” basically the internet would have to be wiped out, along with most of the people who ever used or installed Armory (including all the people who ever understood the code). Not only that, but the algorithm for converting your paper backup to your signing keys is publicly available, and could easily be implemented in other applications without needing Armory. In other words, it's effectively impossible for this to happen.

text:
as <@U0BRLU4PL> mentioned, it looks like Armory supports multisig "lockboxes" (arbitrary m-of-n transaction vault implementation) as well:
"A board of three directors maintaining funds for their organization — those funds cannot be spent unless any two of those directors agrees. Bigger multi-signature transactions are possible for bigger organizations, such as 3-of-5, 5-of-9, etc."
They have an interesting "cold storage" system where the guts of your information resides on a never-connected-to-the-Internet-and-never-will-be computer
this does what we want: <https://bitcoinarmory.com/tutorials/armory-advanced-features/lockbox/spend-lockbox/>
well, Coinbase is set up, so let's mess with that first
and I'll set something up to check out Armory  in a bit
probs Winter Break :simple_smile:
On paribus: ~5$ in 2-3 months. Some set up issues but I expect it to pay back the time spent even with my low rate of purchase.
<@U0A6XP8JF> The puddle is a comforting back up. I have yet to make use of it but have reduced my cash holding slightly as a result
I've initiated a withdrawal of $0.0039899 BTC ($1.21) from the ASCA vault on Coinbase.
<@U0A6T0LNT|brandon> uploaded a file: <https://gwusbdhdu.slack.com/files/brandon/F0DBS8M8E/asca-2015-10-28-iv.png|asca-2015-10-28-IV.png>
a few minutes ago, I also initiated and then cancelled a withdrawal of the same magnitude from the ASCA vault on Coinbase.
I'm already less nervous about Coinbase than I am about Puddle
Coinbase has a very friendly interface, though I already know it to be less flexible and powerful than Armory
in the interest of a comprehensive discussion, I want to test multiple options :simple_smile:
unsurprisingly, Armory has a cold storage client (store the important stuff on a machine that's never touched the Internet) for Raspberry Pi: <https://bitcoinarmory.com/download/>
<@U0A6XP8JF>, <@U0A6Z2QE4>, <@U0A6V6PHS>: thoughts on decommissioning the Puddle now or waiting a bit?
for those following along at home: <http://www.andhigherstill.com/2015/05/stretch-your-emergency-fund-with-puddle.html>

attachments.title: Stretch Your Emergency Fund with Puddle | And Higher Still
attachments.text: Used properly with a group you trust, an ASCA can diversity away liquidity risk and help everyone's emergency funds go further!
attachments.fallback: And Higher Still: Stretch Your Emergency Fund with Puddle | And Higher Still

text: earlier in the year I spent an enormous amount of effort looking into other ways to create an Accumulated Savings and Credit Association [ASCA] using traditional financial tools, and it turned out to be a pretty big pain
Puddle greatly simplified the mechanics of establishing an ASCA... but who the eff is Puddle?
Bitcoin m-of-n multisig wallets are the answer, and should allow us to store money in a context where the storing company has zero access to the funds
and we're trying to configure things 'just so', so that _we_ will have access to the stored funds even if the storing company (in this case Coinbase) bites the dust
...and yes, that means that our shared emergency fund supplement would be stored in bitcoin
that has so many advantages it's hard to ignore
if we are going to assume that bitcoin is going to do well for itself in the long-term, that also solves the "I'm storing lots of money in Puddle and it's not earning anything" sadness
Speaking of the so many advantages that are hard to ignore...what are they?
<@U0A6XP8JF|zach> uploaded a file: <https://gwusbdhdu.slack.com/files/zach/F0DC33ERH/pasted_image_at_2015_10_28_12_32_pm.png|hmmmm>
ah my bad
it got double pasted
It’s unclear to me how to withdraw from the ASCA

I don't think you're able to withdraw from the ASCA, Zach.  The relationship between the co-signers is asymmetric (in the CoinBase interface).  Brandon has to initiate a withdrawal, and then a majority of co-signers have to sign off on it in order for it to go through.
but it’s symmetric outside of the coinbase interface, yeah?
Yeah.
I guess if you wanted it to be symmetric using the coinbase system
you would all share an account but it wouldn’t be a cosigner
does the system allow that?
Coinbase wants to know who you are, etc etc
Coinbase has some of the same problems Puddle does, e.g. I'm the pool owner and I can unilaterally change all of the pool settings
Puddle lets anyone borrow anytime
in puddle you can always take your ball and leave though
as the 'Coinbase ASCA operator' I would need to initiate, you would need to verify, and then I would transfer the funds to whomever
yes, and that's a good point
with multisig, the majority could tell you to go eff yourself
your money is ours now, hah hah hah
Puddle doesn't have that problem*‡
except it does, because I can withdraw as much money as I want, default on the loan, and be banned from the service, but you don't get your cash back
and the amount I can steal is limited only by 1) the amount of money in the ASCA, 2) the amount of money I have contributed, and 3) the borrowing:contribution ratio
if we set up a community organization and opened an organization bank account at a credit union and issued debit cards, the amount any one person can steal is only all of the money
and if someone loses a debit card, the amount the debit card finder can steal is only all of the money
(private key = public key, :smh:)
multisig in general is vulnerable to tyranny of the majority
non-multisig is vulnerable to straight-up unilateral theft
for an ASCA, asymmetric multisig *_at best_* adds an extra step (the operator must transfer the disbursement)

Coinbase: "A group vault requires email confirmations from multiple different users when the owner (you) requests a withdrawal.  No one else can create a withdrawal, but a certain number of approvals are needed before funds can be withdrawn, either 2-of-3 or 3-of-5."
the asymmetry is a reduction in functionality, at best
at worst it's a nightmare
if we can engineer around Coinbase, we solve the dependence on Coinbase and the asymmetry
but we're still limited by Coinbase's arbitrary configuration limitations, meaning m-of-n wallets can only be 2-of-3 or 3-of-5
I don't think that Coinbase's vaults are really designed for ASCA usage.
Armory offers *decentralized symmetric multisig* with *arbitrary m-of-n configurations* and *offline key storage*
I think the point is "I have a lot of bitcoins, and I don't want anyone to get into my account and steal them all".
totally agreed, I think Armory is the choice for an ASCA
So the co-signers are really a mechanism to defend against unauthorized use of the account.
exactly
someone should tell them about ASCAs
But I'll authorize your transaction nonetheless.
:smile:
can you _contribute_ to the multisig vault as a cosigner?
what does ASCA stand for?
oh, actually probably not
Accumulated Savings and Credit Association
Nope, nothing like that in the interface.
In fact, I don't even see the BTC address for the account.
So I think that's really not part of the design spec.
affirmative, it's _really really_ asymmetric
because I can see that stuff
you guys are just making sure that I am me
so no one steals my $4
freaking Bitcoin blockchain is a zillion GB now

Yeah, the zillion GB blockchain is the one part of the technology that seems poorly spec-ed to me right now.  What happens when adoption increases and transaction throughput grows by one or more orders of magnitude?
in Satoshi's original paper, they discuss pruning
Yeah, I know.
and Bitcoin Core v10 has pruning fully implemented and ready to go
and people are experimenting with a bunch of other distributed storage options
so that a client only needs to download a small proportion of the entire blockchain
I think it'll be solved and it won't be a big problem
but yeah, the network's current throughput isn't fantastic and 50GB is a lot of storage
Yep, it's pretty fat for now.

"For P2SH however, the entire script must not exceed 520 bytes.  This effectively limits you to 15 of 15 multisig (7 of 7 if using uncompressed keys).  See 520 byte limit. For the tx to be "Standard" the ScriptSig must be less than 500 bytes so that limits you to 7 signatures (i.e. 7 of 15 or 7 of 7).  A larger "m" (i.e. 8 of 15) is still valid but it isn't standard and won't be relayed by most nodes."
<https://bitcoin.stackexchange.com/questions/23893/what-are-the-limits-of-m-and-n-in-m-of-n-multisig-addresses/28104#28104>

text: (wondering why Armory limits you to 7-of-7 multisig)
Armory is pretty sweet
you run it, it spits out a bunch of text, you send that text out to the signatories, they sign it, it spits out text that they send back to you, and then you assemble the signatures and fire away

for initial setup, all you have to do is install it, create a personal wallet, and back that sucka up
once we know what 'n' is, we'll have to decide on 'm' for our m-of-n lockbox
Gotta reinstall Linux first
and then all 'n' people share the public key of a personal wallet to create the lockbox
another very exciting feature: "simulfund promissory notes"
let's say I want to raise money for, say, some sort of Open Innovation Scholarship
you can create a contribution agreement
and no one puts any money in until everyone agrees on the agreement
if you have a bunch of parties and they don't all 100% trust eachother to be prompt, this ensures that something is funded 100% all at once by everyone, or not at all
Holy Hell, Bitcoin Armory is feckin' slick!
So well designed.
Hmmmmm...
<@U0BRLU4PL> <@U0A6T0LNT>
Is this a thing to be aware of?  <https://lists.linuxfoundation.org/pipermail/bitcoin-dev/2015-September/010798.html>
I'm having trouble downloading the blockchain.
Never mind, looks like it was an overreaction by the Internet.  Imagine that.

text: Although the Bitcoin Armory client was having some trouble getting things initialized on my system, so I'm just using the vanilla client to do that first.
It took me an entire day even on the super-fast campus hardline, but it downloaded the entire blockchain and set everything up successfully
hmm, I should set up a home node too :simple_smile:
hooray for more nodes!
hmmm very little hard drive space remaining :disappointed:
my home desktop has a 120GB SSD and a 1TB RAID1 mirror
the mirror is rsynced with my work desktop and a closet server in PA
the SSD is... wat.
45GB Ext4 with Ubuntu 14.04 LTS
2.0GB swap (kind of pointless with 32GB of RAM)
...and a 73GB Windows NTFS partition?!
I must have habitually set up a Win7 dual-boot back in 2011, but I don't think I've ever been in there
definitely not needed, will remove now, but it also seems kind of silly to store the 50GB blockchain on an SSD
Yeah, you certainly don't need the low latency for this.
I'm only 2 years and 51 weeks behind the current blockchain!
:neutral_face:
but it wouldn't really _hurt_, since it's just downloaded and sitting there, right?
Sure, it's not like it's rapidly reading and writing over and over again.
If you have an external drive you cab copy the data files for the blockchain
And even the index files, although I recommend building those yourself
Actually disk io is pretty important when building the index
Lots if random reads
Hmm, interesting.  Does this happen frequently as additional blocks are generated?
random reads = a-okay, it's repetitive localized writes that cause problems for SSDs!

text: <@U0BRLU4PL>, have you played around with any other cryptocurrencies? <https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Zerocoin>

"Zerocoins are purchased with bitcoin in fixed denominations by a zerocoin mint transaction. Later, these zerocoins can be redeemed for bitcoin to a different bitcoin address by a zerocoin spend transaction. Through the use of cryptographic accumulators and digital commitments with zero-knowledge proofs, it is not possible to link the bitcoin address that was used to mint the original zerocoin to the bitcoin address used to redeem the zerocoin."
Yep.  That's real math.
neato
zero-knowledge proofs are cool
I heard about this idea some time ago -- is this something that there's interest for in the broader community?
Yeah, they're pretty sweet.
<https://bitnodes.21.co/>
